repnme.cdata!:
Increasing agricultural productivity
            through improved drainage : Egypt's national drainage
            projects I and II

abstracts.cdata!:
Egypt's agriculture sector provides
            more than a third of national employment. Almost two-thirds
            of the poor live in rural areas and are primarily dependent
            on agriculture and related industries for survival. Arable
            land resources are extremely limited, consisting of a narrow
            strip along the Nile River amounting to less than 5 percent
            of the country's total land area. Agriculture, except
            for the Mediterranean littoral and desert oases, is almost
            totally dependent on the Nile and the irrigation and
            drainage it provides. Water availability is limited, and a
            major planning goal is to maximize the returns from this
            resource in an environmentally sustainable manner. The
            project also focused on creating institutional and community
            mechanisms for the development and maintenance of the
            systems, and for cost recovery. This included organizing
            farmers into drainage associations, known as collector user associations.

repnme.cdata!:
Egypt - Second Pumping Stations
            Rehabilitation and National Drainage Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Mixed ratings are conveyed through the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR), ICR review, and
            those of this audit process, in regards to the Second
            Pumping Stations Rehabilitation Project, which ranks project
            outcomes as moderately unsatisfactory in contrast to
            satisfactory ratings by the ICR; unlikely sustainability as
            opposed to likely by the ICR, and uncertain by the ICR
            review; negligible institutional development impacts in
            contrast to substantial by both the ICR and ICR review; and,
            both Bank and Borrower performances are downgraded to
            unsatisfactory from satisfactory by the ICR and ICR review.
            However, ratings on the National Drainage Project fully
            concur on satisfactory project outcomes, likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development
            impacts, and satisfactory Bank and Borrower performances.
            Experiences offer two lessons. First, it is reinforced that
            disbursement, and physical achievements are not always good
            indicators of project success, aggravated if failure to
            address systemic institutional problems, adversely affect
            operational efficiency and sustainability of project works,
            making lending ineffective. This not only hampers the
            Bank's reform agenda, but causes also concern among the
            Bank's development partners, who see the Bank as the
            interlocutor capable of advancing institutional, and policy
            reforms with the Government of Egypt. Second, it should be
            taken into consideration the fact that in-country Bank
            partnership with bilateral development agencies, is a
            powerful instrument for institutional reform, who develop
            long-term institution-building relationships with government
            in specific sectors, potentially, and significantly
            increasing the utility, relevance, and leverage of Bank
            assistance. In Egypt, bilateral agencies bring differing
            perspectives to the water, and agriculture sub-sector, and
            are notably strong at capacity building in drainage, and
            community development.

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            and project sustainability is adjudged as likely. Overall
            World Bank performance has been satisfactory, in that it
            maintained realism and flexibility, as its staff kept
            themselves focused on the project's development
            objectives. Similarly, Borrower performance overall has been
            satisfactory, which has resulted in the successful
            implementation of the project. Lessons learned include the
            following: Flexibility was the key to success in this type
            of project--a flexible approach was used in selecting and
            prioritizing areas for installing new sub-surface drainage
            or for their rehabilitation. Also, the Bank and implementing
            agency maintained flexibility in the program to reallocate
            resources to cover urgently needed areas, which arose during
            implementation. In the Egyptian context, the project
            implementation timetable should give full consideration to
            the length of time required between board approval and
            effectiveness because Parlaiment does not often ratify
            loan/credit agreements within a short period. Further
            institutional building is needed to computerize the design
            process, the operation and maintenance of the drainage
            system, and the monitoring and evaluation of drainage
            impacts. Crop compensation should be incorporated into the
            drainage installation contract to be paid directly to
            farmers to circumvent delays.

18154125.admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa
18154125.theme: Water resource management,Pollution management and environmental health,Land administration and management,Rural services and infrastructure
18154125.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objectives of the project
            are to:  (a) increase agricultural productivity by
            evacuating excess water and salts from undrained areas,
            reversing the current land deterioration trend; and (b)
            improve institutional planning and the implementation
            capacity of the drainage subsector.  This project finances a
            six-year period of the National Drainage Program (NDP),
            covering about 720,000 feddans (fed) and encompassing the
            installation or replacement of subsurface drains and the
            remodeling of existing open drains throughout the Nile
            Valley and Delta. Vertical drains will be installed as a
            pilot effort on 5,000 feddans. Technical assistance and
            training will be provided to address contractor weaknesses
            and to assist in the strengthening of EPADP. A coordinated
            monitoring and evaluation program will be introduced.
            Special emphasis will be given to adaptive research for
            drain installation in unstable soils, drainage in heavy clay
            soils, vertical drainage and the used of PVC pipe for
            collectors. In order to reduce fiscal constraints, an
            improved system for the recovery of investment and O&M
            costs related to subsurface drainage will be worked out and implemented.
